awd_titl_txt: Stochastic Analysis of Random Multifractal Measures
awd_abstract_narration:
Fractals are defined by the repetition or near-repetition of a pattern on infinitely many scales. They appear extensively in nature and are prevalent in human-generated data such as financial time series, sound files, and internet traffic patterns. By their very nature fractals are rough, non-differentiable objects that cannot be studied by the classical mathematical methods of calculus. The more modern tools of multifractal analysis, which quantify the degree of roughness that appears on various scales, can be used instead. It is particularly interesting to apply multifractal analysis to randomly generated objects, which by default tend to exhibit fractal behavior. Random measures, which for example describe the rainfall distribution over a particular state or the distribution of energy in turbulent fluid flows, are a particularly fruitful area for employing multifractal analysis. The results of such an analysis can often be used for prediction and forecasting of the underlying random system. This research project aims to further develop the mathematical foundations for analysis of multifractal properties.

The aim of this project is to analyze the multifractal properties of a broad class of random measures that appear in models of statistical mechanics. The focus will be on random pinning models, random polymer models, random measures arising in two-dimensional conformally invariant systems, and spectral measures of random matrices. In all cases, the major quantity of interest will be the multifractal spectrum, which quantifies the amount of mass the random measure assigns around various points in the space. Computation of the multifractal spectrum is closely related to the theory of large deviations for computing the decay of probabilities of rare events. Many of the tools from that theory will be employed in this project, including the notion of Gibbs condition for describing the most likely behavior of the random system when a rare event occurs. As all the random measures listed above can be described using tools from stochastic analysis, specifically the Wiener chaos decomposition, a particular goal of this project will be to incorporate tools from stochastic analysis into this theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Multifractal spectrum is a way of describing the different scales of roughness that appear in fractal objects. Real world examples of such fractals include the jagged coastlines of countries, the spatial structure of fault lines, and pricing charts of financial assets. Fractal objects are a hallmark of processes created with random inputs, and significant effort is spent on quantifying the exact nature of their multifractal properties.

 
Typically such fractals come equipped with a natural measure, which describes how the "mass" of the fractal varies at different locations. The measure also provides a way of randomly selecting points on the fractal, with those with more mass having a higher probability of being selected. This framework allows for the powerful tools of probability theory to be brought to bear, especially a set of tools called stochastic analysis. The main focus of this project was to build novel ways of using these tools to determine multifractal properties of a random measure. This approach naturally blends probability theory with geometry in a highly theoretical framework, but one that also has immediate applications in real world examples.

     
In this project we studied the multifractal properties of random measures arising from different models within probability theory and statistical physics. Examples were taken from random matrix theory, from models of polymer fluids, and from two-dimensional random geometries. We combined stochastic analysis tools with a general approach called size biasing, which studies the mass held by the measure in a neighborhood of a typical point. By combining size biased quantities with probabilities of finding atypical points, the full multifractal spectrum of the random measure can be derived. This analysis is similar to and partially based on the theory of large deviations, which precisely estimates the probabilities of rare events occurring. In this way, the analysis of multifractal spectrum contributes to the body of knowledge on estimating rare but potentially catastrophic events. In the context of the examples listed above this includes the severity of coastal flooding events due to geometry of the coastline, earthquake frequency owing to the fractal geometry of fault lines, and prediction of market crashes based on the fractal patterns in asset prices. Several publications were produced that explain and make use of this unified framework in the context of these probabilistic models.


The project provided many opportunities for research and training of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows. The results of this research were disseminated via public outreach activities such as presentations at a local Science Day for high school student and a Science at Breakfast event for local industry leaders. The PI also gave presentations in outreach activities meant to increase mathematics awareness for the general public, such as Math Circles and a High School Summer Mathematics program.
